learning_outcomes.description: comprehend and appreciate the law and regulatory processes applicable to international trade and e-commerce, particularly the relevance to contract law, financial regulation and online content regulation; and the implications of the law of e-commerce for bankers, merchants and commercial parties;
recognise legal problems associated with international trade and e-commerce; use legal reasoning in the analysis of such problems; and apply legal principles to solve such problems;
appreciate the business and social contexts in which international trade and e-commerce operate and are regulated; and
identify and appreciate aspects of international trade and electronic commerce and commerce and related applications that give rise to business, ethical and legal issues.

assessments.task_description:
1. The assignment question will be released in week 1.
  2. Length - No more than 2,500 words in length. There will be a 5% penalty for each 10% of part thereof for papers that exceed the word limit. A penalty will be levied at the rate of 10% of the marks available for the assessment item per day that the assessment is overdue. The date and time of submission will be deemed to be that noted on the electronic submission. Assessment submitted more than 7 days after the due date and time will receive zero marks.
  3. The student's name and number must appear at the top of the page.
  4. All authorities must be properly referenced and cited following the Australian Guide to Legal Citation (4th edition). When referencing internet sites include eg "Visited 23 March 2025". A complete bibliography must be included. Footnotes are not counted in the word count provided they are used as footnotes; that is for citations or perhaps as one-line comments.
  5. Students should seek to show that they can comprehend the material and present it accurately; analyse legislation and cases (where applicable); discern the principles and policies which underlie rules; produce critical review; and develop innovative answers to difficult cases.
  6. Technological failure is not a ground for the granting of an extension. Students preparing assignments on computers should ensure that programs are backed up.
  7. Students are expected to undertake original research themselves, using appropriate original sources (legislation and cases), textbooks, academic and professional journals and electronic information technology.
  8. Whilst students may use Artificial Intelligence (AI) and/or Machine Translation (MT) technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct Policy. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignments must be submitted electronically via the submission link on the course Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Students will be required to answer three questions out of four. All questions are of equal value.

This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct Policy.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 2 To Week 11(03 Mar - 18 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Seminars

The seminar topics are available from the course Blackboard site.

Seminar topics:

  1. Introduction – International Trade practices and management - Resources - Use of Technology
  2. The use of Incoterms in International trade - Private International Law - Incoterms 2020
  3. The Financing of International Trade - (1) Open Account - (2) Credit - (3) Letters of Credit; UCP, eUCP, BPO - (4) Bills of Exchange and the ML-ETR
  4. Contracts - The Electronic Transactions Acts - UN Electronic Communications Convention and UNCITRAL Model Laws (E) - Electronic Bills of Lading.
  5. International Sale of Goods CISG and electronic contracts (ECC Article 20)
  6. Carriage of Goods by Sea – Bills of Lading and the ML-ETR – Marine Insurance
  7. Mediation and Arbitration – Online Dispute Resolution processes - Management of Intellectual Property in International Trade – Keeping Records – Evidence of Electronic Documents
  8. Blockchain and Bitcoin and Smart Contracts - Artificial Intelligence and Robotics Law; Innovation – Autonomous Shipping – Transport Revolution

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
